transcripts.text: Let me ask you on another exercise of presidential power.  The New Yorker is reporting this morning that the president ordered the Department of Justice to attempt to block the merger between AT&T and Time Warner over the objections of his chief of staff then, John Kelly, but also his chief white economic advisor, Gary Cohn.  In your view, is that an acceptable use of presidential power, a president trying to block a merger because he doesn't like the coverage by a news station this one owned by one of the companies involved?

well number one i don't know if it's true.  i think the report yet again was based on anonymous sources.  uh number two i think it's perfectly acceptable for uh the president united states to have an opinion to block a merger.
to block a merger to to punish what what he considers a critic.

I don't think that it's been established.  I know it's been alleged that that was what his mental perspective was at the time, and I think it's all anonymous sources.  I don't know what the president thought, and neither do you, frankly.  None of us do.  I mean, it's an anonymous source.  Once again, talking to the New York Times.
Well, it's the New Yorker I should cite.  But if the president were to do that, would you consider that an acceptable use of presidential power?

Well, I don't think that's a fair question because they had been proven that he did it.  I mean, if any public official committed murder, would I think that's wrong?  If he committed murder, yeah, he'd be a murderer.
Well, the president also, even in campaign statements, said publicly that he opposed the merger.  So this didn't come out of the blue.  I TAKE YOUR POINT.
